BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Over a wide area significant warming.
The wind slabs of the last few days are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. Large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant.
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes above the tree line. In the event of solar radiation caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls. Slides can occur on cut slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last few days. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the day: The strong wind will transport the fresh and old snow. The wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs will form in the course of the day especially above approximately 2000 m.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released even by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m, caution is to be exercised in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.

Dry avalanches can be released in deep layers by large loads. These can reach quite a large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from the afternoon above approximately 2000 m. Until Tuesday the wind will be strong.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is not capable of bearing a load, in particular below approximately 2100 m. Over a wide area various wind slab layers are lying on a hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the day: The strong wind will transport the fresh and old snow. The wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs will form in the course of the day especially above approximately 2000 m.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released even by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m, caution is to be exercised in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.

Dry avalanches can be released in deep layers by large loads. These can reach quite a large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from the afternoon above approximately 2000 m. Until Tuesday the wind will be strong.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is not capable of bearing a load, in particular below approximately 2100 m. Over a wide area various wind slab layers are lying on a hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Over a wide area significant warming. The wind slabs represent the main danger.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France a considerable danger of dry avalanches will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released easily in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m, especially at their margins. As a consequence of warming during the day individual small and medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular along the border with France. Stability tests and field observations have shown poor snowpack stability on steep shady slopes. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Over a wide area significant warming. The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will gradually increase. In the event of solar radiation caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls. Slides can occur on cut slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the day: The strong wind will transport the snow. The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in the course of the day especially above approximately 2000 m.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Especially in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) 5 to 10 cm of snow, but less in some localities, will fall from the afternoon above approximately 2000 m.
Until Tuesday the wind will be strong.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is not capable of bearing a load, in particular below approximately 2100 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Mostly avalanches are only small. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

In addition very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from variable directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. They are lying on weak layers. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. This is particularly the case in the areas with less snow, well off the main Alpine ridge. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of warming during the day mostly small avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2400 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The sometimes deep wind slabs of the weekend must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The sometimes large wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided whenever possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind, wind slabs formed in the last few days in all aspects. The new snow can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. The snowpack is weak in some cases and has a loosely bonded surface. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some regions 5 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1400 m. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days. They can be released easily in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m, especially at their margins. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. As a consequence of warming during the day individual medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported some snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the mostly small wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep shady slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. In particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In the next few hours the weather will be cold. Below approximately 1000 m a little snow is lying. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. Small avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some regions 5 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of warming during the day mostly small avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
